messageBody:
Sean Machin wrote:

> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks for the response Jason,
> > > > > but WebStart is just the mechanism for launching Java
> > apps, > we
> > > use it > > here to launch our suite of Swing based client apps. I
> > > > would like to
> > > > > test successful downloading and launching of the apps from
> > > > the server
> > > > > via WebStart, I guess I am looking for WebStartUnit...
> > > >
> > > > I think you are /writing/ WebStartUnit... although not
> > necessarily.
> > > >
> > > > Use me as a virtual pair. Describe how you would test
> > this manually.
> > > > --
> > >
> > > J.B.,
> > >
> > > What I would ideally like is a means to specify from a unit
> > test the
> > > URL of a WebStart app. to launch, then get back some indication of
> > > whether it launched OK, or some error codes if something
> > went wrong.
> > > Currently we have to test this manually by clicking on each
> > app's link
> > > on the WebStart page and verifying the app. is downloaded
> > and launched
> > > successfully.
> >
> > What criteria do you use to determine whether the application is
> > downloaded and launched successfully? I assume that you look at a web
> > page and judge "pass" or "fail". Can you put that information in an
> > HTMLUnit test? (You mentioned HTTPUnit. If you're not using HTMLUnit,
> > start.)
> >
> > I don't understand WebStart, so you'll have to explain to me
> > how I would
> > know that a WebStart-served application ran correctly.
> > --
> J.B.,
>
> For some info on WebStart see http://java.sun.com/products/javawebstart/
> It's basically a mechanism for downloading Java apps (e.g. Swing apps)
> by
> clicking on a link on a webpage. The WebStart software on the client
> machine
> then fetches the jars (if not previously cached) and runs the program
> locally
> on the client machine. Think of it like applets "Next Generation".
>
> To verify our app's are running correctly after a build/deploy cycle,
> we need to click the link on a webpage for each app, observe WebStart
> download each app. without error and observe each (Swing) app. start
> correctly (e.g. show it's initial login screen).
>
> Thus there's not much to test on the HTTP side of things apart from
> ensuring each link is valid...

Well, off the top of my head there are two approaches.

1. Use Microsoft's ScriptIt or whatever is appropriate for your
platform. This is software that allows you to monitor OS-level windows,
click widgets on them and verify the contents of windows. It may help.

2. Find out what mechanism is launching the WebStart application locally
and see whether there is a Java interface to it through something like
RMI. If there is, then your test goes like this:

use HTTPConnection to click the link
connect to the WebStart server
sleep for some reasonable amount of time
verify that the WebStart server is running/has launched the desired app

Does any of that help? Does anyone have a more brute approach?
